title: Has there ever been a black pope? - Quora

response.answer_text: Despite what millions of paintings, statues, TV shows and movies (up to and including the current "History" Channel mini-series) might want you to think, the Catholic Church wasn't started by a bunch of white guys.  Was there ever a black pope? That depends on your definition of "black", pretty much. Jesus and St. Peter - traditionally the first pope - certainly had African ancestry. There was all that time that the Jews spent in Egypt, for one thing, and, well, look at a map. It's not exactly a long way from Jerusalem to Africa. There were probably some people going back and forth. As Eric Stoltz mentions, there were also three African popes, all of whom are believed to have been of Berber descent. Does that make them black? Well, it makes them African, but not sub-Saharan African. Does that "count" as black?  So, in my opinion, the answer to your question is that there isn't an answer to your question. Has there ever been a pope that was as dark-skinned as Cardinal Peter Turkson? Probably not. But there certainly several that were a lot darker than Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger.

Of course. 31, to be exact. Superior General of the Society of Jesus - Wikipedia “The Superior General of the Society of Jesus is the official title of the leader of the Society of Jesus – the Roman Catholic religious order which is also known as the Jesuits. He is generally addressed as Father General. The position sometimes carries the nickname of the Black Pope, because of his responsibility for the largest Catholic, male religious order and is contrasted to the white garb of the pope. The thirty-first and current Superior General is the Reverend Father Arturo Sosa, elected by the 36th General Congregation on October 14, 2016.” Just, uh, don’t call him that, though.  New general of the Jesuits: I do not like being called "the black pope" Interestingly enough, Pope Francis himself is a Jesuit, and the first one.

In the early years of the Church, there were at least three popes from Africa: Victor I in the Second Century; Miltiades in the Fourth Century and Gelasius I in the Fifth Century.  However, although their place of origin was recorded, their race was not. It would never have occurred to the people of the Roman Empire at that time to record the color of someone's skin, as race is a relatively modern construct. For them, ethnic diversity was so common that it was not even worth comment. So we have three African popes. Were they black, or dark-skinned people of North Africa along the Mediterranean (like Egyptians) or were they children of Roman colonists? We'll never know, but odds are at least one of them was black.

I take you are not referring to the Jesuits, who wear black robes, and their head has always been referred to as the black pope. Instead, I am assuming you are talking about someone from an African nation. We honestly do not know one way or the other, although it is more than reasonable to assume that several of them might have been from Africa. Before the Muslim invasion and conquest of northern Africa, Catholicism was very strong, and some of our greatest saints came from there. For instance, St. Augustine of Hippo was a north African saint. And it is entirely reasonable to assume that several of our Popes may have come from there in the first six centuries before Christianity was entirely wiped out in Africa.

There have been three North African Popes: the 14th pope, Victor I (189-198 A.D.); the 32nd pope, Miltiades (311-314 A.D.); and the 49th pope, Gelasius I (492-496 A.D.). Since we didn’t have photography and no one cared enough to write down the skin color of the Popes at that time, we don’t really know if they were black. Most North Africans are white, but the Berbers have darker skin. (St. Augustine was probably part Berber). Skin color totally aside, I’m hoping for Cardinal Robert Sarah or Francis Arinze as the next Pope.

From Wikipedia: Catholic Church in Africa - Wikipedia Many important members of the early Church were from Africa, including Mark the Evangelist, Origen, Tertullian, Saint Augustine of Hippo (from Hippo Regius in what is now Annaba, Algeria) and Clement of Alexandria. Churches in eastern North Africa, such as those in Egypt and Ethiopia, tended to align with the practice of the Eastern Church, but those to the West (the area now known as the Maghreb) were connected to the Roman Church. Three early popes were from the Roman Africa Province. These were Pope Victor I (reigned c . 189 to 199), Pope Miltiades (reigned 311 to 314) and Pope Gelasius I (492 to 496) and all of them were Christian Berbers.

Who says there has never been a Black pope? Several of the Popes in the early centuries were from North Africa, that doesn’t mean that they were necessarily black, but that wasn’t something that was recorded either. Before JP2, all of the Bishops of Rome (= Pope) for a long time had been Italian, so we are just now starting to diversify.
No. There were some Northern African Popes (most likely ethnically Berber), but none from the West/East/Southern African regions (or ethnically descended from those places).
Not yet; but there are quite a few black cardinals and it is only a matter of time until one of them becomes Pope
